entry.title: Get all Receipts for an Expense Report in a PDF file
entry.content:
Why This Matters:

Many organizations still rely on the deprecated Reports v2 API to retrieve receipts. However, this API will be decommissioned soon, and continuing to use it creates long-term risks and potential disruption to business processes. Migrating to the supported APIs ensures stability, compliance, and scalability.

Solution Overview:

To retrieve all receipts for an Expense Report in a single PDF file, follow these steps using supported APIs:

Report-Level Receipts:

API Endpoints:

Get the Report ID using Reports v3 API:GET /api/v3.0/expense/reports
Download Report-Level Receipts using Image v1 API:GET https://www.concursolutions.com/api/image/v1.0/report/{reportId}

Entry-Level Receipts:

API Endpoints:

Get Expense Entries for the Report using Entries v3 API:GET https://www.concursolutions.com/api/v3.0/expense/entries?reportID={reportID}
Download Entry-Level Receipts using Image v1 API: GET https://www.concursolutions.com/api/image/v1.0/expenseentry/{entryId}

 

Benefits of This Approach:

  • Uses supported APIs (future-proof).
  • Consolidates all receipts for easier audits and compliance checks.
  • Ensures scalability for clients processing large volumes of reports.
  • Avoids disruption from deprecated functionality.

 

Conclusion:

By transitioning from the deprecated Reports v2 API to the supported Reports v3, Entries v3, and Image v1 APIs, clients can reliably retrieve all receipts from an expense report in a single PDF file. This approach not only ensures compliance with SAP Concur’s supported framework but also provides a scalable, future-proof solution for audit, finance, and compliance needs. Implementing this workflow today helps organizations avoid disruptions tomorrow.

Prerequisites

This post will not discuss authentication with Concur Expense.  Please see this post to get an explanation on authentication and application building within Concur Expense.  You will need an application with the following SCOPEs:

  • EXPRPT
  • IMAGE

entry.title: Re: SAP PUBLIC CLOUD ABAP EML Defintion
entry.content:
Hi @JamesG ,

Hope below information is helpful:

1. Identify the Target Business Object and Operation

 

The "Target Type" is the data structure (or a Business Object type) that the operation component is designed to manipulate or retrieve.

  • Determine the Operation's Purpose: What is the operation component supposed to do? (e.g., CreateSalesOrder, ChangeCustomer, GetMaterialDetails).

  • Identify the Business Object (BO): The BO is the real-world entity the operation acts upon (e.g., SalesOrder, Customer, Material).

 

2. Determine the Target Type from the Target System's Interface

 

The "Target Type" will be the structured data type—often a BAPI structure or an OData Entity Type—that represents the business object on the back-end system (like SAP S/4HANA or SAP ECC).

ScenarioTarget Type SourceWhere to Check
Connecting to SAP ECC/S/4HANA (using BAPIs/RFCs)BAPI Structure/Interface TypeUse transaction SWO1 (Business Object Builder) or SE37 (Function Builder) in the back-end SAP system to find the exact structure used for the Import, Export, and Table parameters of the corresponding BAPI/RFC function module.
Connecting to an OData Service (SAP Fiori/CDS View based)OData Entity TypeCheck the OData service's $metadata document. The Target Type is the specific Entity Type (e.g., SalesOrderType, C_SalesOrderTP) that the BOI operation maps to.
Connecting to a Custom BTP Application (CAP/RAP)Service Entity/StructureThe Target Type is the entity or structure defined in the Core Data Services (CDS) model of the application (e.g., com.sap.internal.bo.SalesOrder).

entry.title: Seeing Skills Before They Matter: People Intelligence in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Seeing Skills Before They Matter: People Intelligence in SAP SuccessFactors

In HR, we’ve always had a knack for reporting the past — headcount, attrition, training hours, compensation trends. But what if we could flip the script and start looking ahead? What if we could see the skills that will matter tomorrow, and act on them today?

That’s exactly what People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud is helping us do — and it’s something I believe every HR leader should be paying attention to.

The Challenge: Too Much Data, Too Little Insight

Let’s face it — most of us aren’t short on data. We’re drowning in it. The real issue is that it’s scattered across systems: recruiting, learning, payroll, performance, time tracking. Each one tells part of the story, but none give us the full picture.

So when we’re asked questions like:

  • “What skills will we need in 12 months?”
  • “Are we training people in the right areas?”
  • “Do we have the right talent mix for our growth plans?”

we often end up guessing, or reacting too late.

What’s Different with People Intelligence in SAP SuccessFactors?

This is where SAP SuccessFactors integrated with Business Data Cloud really changes the game. It brings together all your HR data — securely and intelligently — and turns it into forward-looking insights.

Here’s what stood out to me:

  • Connected, Trusted HR Data

People Intelligence automatically harmonizes data from across SAP SuccessFactors — Employee Central, Learning, Recruiting, Compensation, and more. No more spreadsheets. No more silos.

  • Predictive Insights with SAP Business AI

It’s not just about dashboards. You can ask questions like:

  • “Which skills are trending upward in our engineering teams?”
  • “If we expand in Southeast Asia, do we have the right talent mix?”

The system uses AI to surface risks, model scenarios, and suggest actions — before problems arise.

  • Natural Language with Joule

This is a game-changer. Instead of building reports, you just ask:
“Do we have enough cybersecurity talent in EMEA?”
Joule understands the context, pulls the data, and gives you a clear, actionable answer.

  • Cross-Functional Alignment

Finance, operations, and HR can now work off the same data foundation. That means workforce planning is finally aligned with business strategy — not an afterthought.

Real Business Impact

This isn’t just about better analytics. It’s about better outcomes:

  • Spot skill gaps before they slow down the business
  • Reduce emergency hiring costs
  • Align learning investments with future needs
  • Elevate HR’s role in strategic planning

A Few Real-World Scenarios

  • A tech company sees demand for AI/ML skills doubling. They launch upskilling programs now — not when it’s too late.
  • A manufacturing firm plans a new plant. People Intelligence helps them confirm contractor availability in the region — avoiding delays.
  • A consulting firm simulates growth models and sees how skill availability affects project timelines — before committing.

My Take

People Intelligence isn’t just another HR tool. It’s a mindset shift — from reactive to predictive, from fragmented to unified. It gives HR leaders the visibility and confidence to act before skills gaps become business risks.

If you’re using SAP SuccessFactors, this is something you should explore. It’s not just about data — it’s about decisions.

Learn more about People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud

Over to you:
What skills do you think will be most critical for your organization in the next 1–2 years? Let’s start a conversation.

entry.title: Re: ME23N Display Purchase Order: Output is blank
entry.content:
Some of the reasons why NEU still fails when you manually add it in ME22N

  • Incomplete key fields: When you add NEU, you must also fill medium, partner function, and language. If any are missing or inconsistent with vendor master data, the record won’t be saved to NAST.
  • Output determination procedure not assigned: Check in customizing (SPRO → MM → Purchasing → Messages → Output Control → Message Determination Schemas → Assign Schema to Document Type). If the PO’s document type doesn’t have a schema with NEU, the system won’t accept it.
  • Condition record missing: Even if you add NEU manually, the system may reject it if no valid condition record exists (transaction MN04 for NEU). That’s why new POs work (condition records fixed) but old ones don’t.
  • Change message indicator: For existing POs, if the “message determination” indicator isn’t set (e.g. no change flagged), the system won’t trigger output.
  • NAST update blocked: If the PO was created before config was corrected, the system never wrote a NAST entry. Adding NEU now may not work unless you also trigger a change that re‑evaluates output.

entry.title: Best Practices for Pay Transparency in SuccessFactors Recruiting
entry.content:
Show me the money!

It’s not just candidates asking anymore, though, now it’s the law.

More and more often, employers are being required to share pay information with prospective candidates when posting job opportunities.  Many have chosen to post this information even when it’s not mandatory.  However, different locations have different requirements about what must be posted.  So how should you configure your SuccessFactors instance to be compliant with pay transparency laws?

I’m going to outline the steps to take to properly configure SuccessFactors Recruiting for pay transparency.  First, though, we need to make a few assumptions:

  • The employer has pay ranges in their job architecture for each job.
  • The employer is using SuccessFactors Recruiting Management, Recruiting Marketing, and Employee Central with Position Management.
  • The employer wishes to allow recruiters to edit the pay information that is posted on requisitions, to accommodate for things such as union requirements or localization.

Step 1:  Define Posting Range Fields on Requisition

The standard minimum and maximum pay fields need to be defined on the requisition, so they can be auto-populated with data from the job architecture.  The pay range fields that are posted need to be text fields, so they can be mapped to Recruiting Marketing properly.  Because these posting fields are only used for Recruiting purposes, they don’t belong in the job architecture.  They should be populated on a requisition and used only for that requisition.

You can do this configuration in Admin Center>Manage Templates or via Provisioning, using an xml editor:

Don’t forget to permission the fields.  Typically, the standard minimum and maximum pay fields are read-only, as they will be auto-populated.  The posting range fields are editable so the recruiting operator can edit them or add context.  If you don’t wish to allow editing, you could set business rules to auto-populate them, and even hide them from the user.  You might also want to update other settings, such as making these fields reportable.

 Step 2:  Set Business Rules to Populate Pay Ranges

Set up the business rule to map position data to the requisition, including the salaryMin and salaryMax fields.  You may also want to include other fields like salaryMid or paygrade.

Admin Center>Configure Business Rules

Once populated, this is how the fields will look on a requisition:

When populating these fields, keep your end goal in mind.  If your jobs will be reposted on job boards that require only an amount in these fields, don’t add additional comments within the fields.

Step 3:  Map Posting Fields to Recruitment Marketing

The fields from the requisition need to be mapped to Recruiting Marketing so they can be posted.  Each needs to be in a discrete field so job boards can properly use this data.  If you are concerned about using the limited custom fields available, you can also repurpose standard fields for mapping.

Step 5:  Relabel Recruitment Marketing Fields

In Recruiting Marketing, you’ll need to update translations so the fields you created have the correct labels.  Find the standard fields you mapped in Step 4 and update the labels to match the fields as defined on the requisition.

Career Site Builder>Tools>Translations

Step 6:  Add Posting Fields to Job Layouts

Add the fields to your job layout in Recruiting Marketing.  This will allow the job posting to display these fields discreetly, rather than including them in the text of the job description.

Career Site Builder>Layouts>Job

When the job is posted, these fields will be available for candidates to see, and will also be available if posting partners scrape your site.

Step 7:  Include Posting Fields in XML Feeds

If your job postings are being distributed to job boards via xml feed, confirm with the vendor if changes are needed to make sure these pay range fields can be received and used on those third-party postings.  The vendor should be able to tell you the layout that needs to be used.  If changes are needed, you will have to work with an implementation partner or support to update your job feeds.

As pay transparency is becoming part of our everyday, the details are still shifting.  Some places now require you to provide information on available benefits or other compensation.  Some places have different requirements for different sizes of employers.  Many of the laws are still being ironed out and requirements are changing frequently.  Make sure you check with your legal or compliance advisors to ensure you are meeting all the requirements wherever you post job opportunities.

While the necessity of posting pay information has been a big shift in mentality for many employers, studies have shown that candidates are more apt not to apply for positions that don’t meet their needs, thereby reducing the number of candidates recruiters need to screen.  It also offers employers an opportunity to differentiate themselves in other ways, such as company culture and future growth.  The underlying intention is to make this playing field fair for everyone involved, giving us all the information we need to make good decisions.

If you need help meeting these requirements or if you are unsure about what you might need to do, please reach out to us!

entry.title: Re: I'm not getting the same result with my FI-GL validat...
entry.content:
Please note in OB28 validations/substitutions are tied to call points in FI (document header, line item, complete document). In classic transactions (FB01, FB50, F‑02, etc.), the system fills BKPF-TCODE with the actual SAP GUI transaction code. Your validation can check BKPF-TCODE = 'FB01' and it works. In Fiori apps like F0718, the posting is not executed under “FB01” at all. Instead, the app calls the Journal Entry API (BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST / ACC_DOCUMENT) in the background. That means BKPF-TCODE is not populated with FB01. Often it is blank, or filled with a generic technical value. As a result, any validation logic that depends on BKPF-TCODE or “user account” fields behaves differently. This is why you see your validation trigger in FB01 but not in F0718 — it’s normal in S/4HANA.

To fix it, avoid relying on BKPF-TCODE. Instead, use document type, account type, or enrich the posting with a BAdI if you need to distinguish Fiori vs. GUI.

entry.title: Homogeneous Update and Copy to SAP Cloud using RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench
entry.content:
Introduction

In today’s rapidly evolving SAP landscape, customers are increasingly looking for seamless ways to upgrade and migrate their systems to leverage the full potential of SAP S/4HANA and the cloud. As part of the Early Adopter Program, I had the opportunity to work hands-on with the Transition Workbench tool to perform an upgrade from SAP S/4HANA 1909 to SAP S/4HANA 2023 FP03 and subsequently execute a migration to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP).

In this blog, I share my real-world experience from this project — detailing the Update and Tenant Copy methods in SAP BTP Cloud Cockpit, how the Transition Workbench helped streamline the process, and the step-by-step approach I followed to carry out the upgrade and migration successfully. This write-up is designed to help consultants and customers alike understand the practical aspects, challenges, and best practices of such transformations.

I would like to take a moment to recognize and sincerely appreciate the efforts and valuable technical advisory of Ravikiran Chikati, Bharathwaj, Arvind, Srivastava, Piyush and Klumpp, Fabian.  

Overview: Update and Copy to SAP Cloud Cockpit

This process describes how an on-premises SAP S/4HANA or SAP Business Suite (SOH) system is upgraded and replicated to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition environment using the Transition Workbench and the Update & Copy to Cloud Cockpit approach.

The workflow begins with provisioning a skeleton target system and a migration server in the SAP Cloud environment (steps 1 & 2). The Transition Workbench acts as an intermediate layer to streamline preparation, replication, and upgrade tasks (steps 3–5).

On the source side, preparation steps are executed, the SUM tool performs the in-place upgrade, and the download directories are copied between the migration server and the source system (steps 4, 6, 7 & 8).

After ramp-down activities (step 9), the upgrade is completed, and the system is switched back to the main instance (steps 10 & 12). Finally, ECS post-processing ensures that the migrated and upgraded system is ready for productive use (step 13).

This phased approach—covering Pre-Requisite Checks, Software Download, Preparation, Replication, Downtime Finalization, and Post-Processing—helps customers move from an on-premises S/4HANA or SOH system to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP) efficiently and with minimal risk.

Pre-requisite

Provision/Validation of DNS names in RISE environment

Preparatory actions to be performed by ECS

  1. Provision the Migration VM and the Target System

You will receive the Migration VM details together with the handover of the target landscape details.​

Cockpit-Independent Preparatory Actions

Preparation activities required both from ECS and users to access and work with the "system transition workbench"

Preparatory actions to be performed by ECS

The "RISE with SAP system transition workbench" ("system transition workbench") is installed by ECS on a so-called Migration VM. After preparing the Migration VM, ECS hands it over to the migration partner.

Early Adopter program, are not provided by default on the Migration VM

Preparatory actions to be performed by Users

  • The workbench requires access to internet, preconfigured by the user's proxy.
  • Remote Function Call (RFC)
  • RFC requests are used for the communication to the application servers.

Migration VM must have connection to the source system to make RFC calls.

the following source system parameters are required:

  • DDIC user in client 000 of the source system
  • Instance host
  • Domain
  • Instance number

Access to Services and Tools

  • The "system transition workbench" needs to access to the following:
  • The source system and the target SAP HANA database using SQL
  • The Maintenance Planner
  • The analytics service
  • The Software Download Service (SDS)

General Network Requirements

The "system transition workbench" has the following network requirements on the Migration VM:

  • Connection to source and target database using SQL ports
  • Connection to the source application server using remote function call (RFC)
  • Connection to the Maintenance Planner, SAP download services, CRLbag service, and analytics tools

Requirement for Maintenance Planner and HANA Replication

  • The source system must be known to the Maintenance Planner
  • Users must manually create a transaction in the Maintenance Planner
  • Validate all HANA Replication related parameters are applied on source and target database (Refer Pre-req sheet)
  • Validate if Log mode of Source to be Normal and keep monitoring log volume size to store logs to be replicated.
  • Validate if

a) Auto failover should be disabled.

b) Disable Database Hooks: Hooks are HA/DR providers which sends information to initiate auto failover. These can be disabled from global.ini file.

  • Validate if nameserver Service ports needs to be opened in Source System and target system, Range: 3<inst_id><service port> or 3<inst_id>XX. Telnet test can be performed to validated if ports are open

Created the ticket to enable the Migration VM from ECS. You will receive the mail after enabling the Migration VM from ECS. TWB tool has been installed on the migration server. Make sure you are on the latest Version before starting the project 

RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench Version: 0.36.1

SAP System Transition Workbench
Once Enabled the Transition Workbench login to VDI or Citrix of customer access the Below URL

Note: LT1 Migration VM is meant for customer it can be accessed from the Customer Network only

https://<hostname>. <domain_name>:1129/lmsl/slocon/docs/index.html 

Login with user sapadm, if password not available reset at the OS level to get the password.

Create the Vault to secure the password storage, a KeePass Vault is to be created.       It will be encrypted with the vault password you enter.

 Start the Uptime Phase

Uptime Phase has 3 Steps

  1. Pre-requisite Checks
  2. Download
  3. Preparation and Replication

Pre-requisites Checks

Start the Task 1.1: Pre-requisite Checks for Homogenous Conversion to SAP S/4 HANA

Below are the Parameter which needed for Tenant Copy

Source System

Target System

Confirm the setting can be applied to the target database of the productive system

Clear the result with error

Perform the backup of the Source and Target Database within the last 24 hours

Uninstall the LCAPPS and AFL components from the source database as it is not installed on the Target Database

Apply the SAP Note 3409764 in the Source System

Confirm the SAP Note has been applied on the Source System and proceed further

Software Download

Start the Task 2.1: Software Download

Preparation and Replication

Start the Task 3.1: Pre-requisite for Homogeneous Conversion to SAP S/4 HANA

Start the Task 3.2: Initialize and Monitor SAP HANA Replication

Execute the below SQL Statement to check the Replication Status

SELECT DATABASE_NAME, SOURCE_HOST, TARGET_HOST, REPLICATION_STATUS, REPLICATION_STATUS_DETAILS, LAST_LOG_POSITION, LAST_LOG_POSITION_TIME, SHIPPED_LOG_POSITION, SHIPPED_LOG_POSITION_TIME from SYS_DATABASES.M_DATABASE_REPLICA_STATISTICS

Once Replication Status in ACTIVE Status

Copy the Downloaded Directory from LT1 (Migration VM) to Source System

Copy the addons into this Download Directory

Start the SUM on the Source System

SUM Uptime Activities

cd /usr/sap/SID/Cycle2/SUM/abap/

./SUMSTART confighostagent SID

Extraction

SUM URL - https://<hostname>.<domainname>:1129/lmsl/sumabap/SID/slui

Configuration Phase

Checks Phase

Prep-processing Phase

Ramp-down Activities Before downtime

Execution Phase

Post Processing After Downtime

Finalize Replication Steps

Start the Downtime Phase in this phase you have two steps

  1. Finalize
  2. Post-Processing

Start the Task 1.1: Finalize Tenant Replication for Homogeneous Conversion to SAP HANA

Start the Task 2.1: Post-Processing

Confirm and proceed further to complete the Transition workbench

Perform the Post Activities

Execute the Report SHDB_MIGRATION_CHECK

Manual Post Processing

Create the SR Ticket to Switch Application back to Main instance after the Migration

Update hdbuserstore and Check R3trans -d / -x (Validate connection to DB is working on all APPS)

Updated as part of the Switch Main Instance SR

Perform the Post Activities

Silent Data Migration

Go to transaction SDM_MON -> Current Client Info

Run SJOBREPO -> SAP_SDM_EXECUTOR_POSTPROCESSING

Handover to ECS Post Processing

Summary

The RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench is not just a tool - it's your navigation system in the digital transformation landscape. By radically reducing manual efforts, minimizing errors, and streamlining processes, it ensures that your journey to the private cloud is as smooth and efficient as possible. Check out our documentation and early adaptor program and discover how you can leverage this incredible innovation to facilitate your migration endeavors.

entry.title: Use Custom Fields in Account-based Segmentation
entry.content:
Introduction

Corporate Accounts in Emarsys always correspond to a similar object in a sales system (SAP Sales Cloud or a 3rd-party CRM system). Very often such accounts are extended with a lot of custom fields to support specific processes. Such custom fields are often relevant for marketing segmentation as well. Recently the support of custom fields had been added to the Account-based Segmentation feature in Emarsys.

In the case that your current integration setup between your sales system and Emarsys does not yet support the transfer of such custom fields, I'll show you in the following chapters how to create the necessary data using the Corporate Account API.

 

Create Corporate Accounts with Extension Fields

 

Create Extension Fields

The creation of Corporate Account Fields is referenced in the Business Accelerator Hub here. For creation, the API call is a POST with this URL: <Base URL>/api/corporateaccount/v1/extensibilityFields

In that case, you need also a codelist. You can find the reference here. For this, the API call is a PUT with this URL: <Base URL>/api/corporateaccount/v1/codelists/extensibilityCodeLists/<ID of the Field>

Simple Field - Boolean

As a simple example for a custom field, let's choose a boolean field that tells whether the account is in escalation mode or not. (Accounts in escalation mode should probably not get too much marketing  communication.)

POST <Base URL>/api/corporateaccount/v1/extensibilityFields

{
  "fieldName": "Ext_Boolean_Escalation",
  "descriptions": [
    {
      "content": "Escalation [Ext]",
      "languageCode": "EN"
    }
  ],
  "fieldType": "boolean",
  "isCodelist": false,
  "isMultiValue": false
}

Note that I only use one translation in these simple examples. In a realistic scenario, you should, of course, provide all the necessary translations.

Field with a Codelist

For this example, I use the size of the company (number of employees) with distinct size categories. The first step is to create the field itself:

POST <Base URL>/api/corporateaccount/v1/extensibilityFields

{
  "fieldName": "Ext_EmployeeSize",
  "descriptions": [
    {
      "content": "Employee Size [Ext]",
      "languageCode": "EN"
    }
  ],
  "fieldType": "string",
  "length": "10",
  "isCodelist": true,
  "isMultiValue": false
}

The second step is to create the codelist. For this call, you need to use the field name of the previously created field in the last part of the URL:

PUT <Base URL>/api/corporateaccount/v1/codelists/extensibilityCodeLists/Ext_EmployeeSize

[
  {
    "code": "01",
    "descriptions": [
      {
        "content": "1-9",
        "languageCode": "en"
      }     
    ]
  },
  ... some more ...
]

Field with a Multi-Value Codelist

Here let's define a field for secondary industries (beside the main industry). Again, let's create the field first:

POST <Base URL>/api/corporateaccount/v1/extensibilityFields

{
  "fieldName": "Ext_SecondaryIndustries",
  "descriptions": [
    {
      "content": "Secondary Industries [Ext]",
      "languageCode": "EN"
    }
  ],
  "fieldType": "string",
  "length": "10",
  "isCodelist": true,
  "isMultiValue": true
}

And finally the codelist:

PUT <Base URL>/api/corporateaccount/v1/codelists/extensibilityCodeLists/Ext_SecondaryIndustries

[
  {
    "code": "01",
    "descriptions": [
      {
        "content": "Agriculture",
        "languageCode": "en"
      }     
    ]
  },
  ... a lot more ...
]

 

Create or Update Accounts with Extension Fields

After we have now created all the extension fields, it is time to create or update an account with values for those fields.

POST or PUT <Base URL>/api/corporateaccount/v1/accounts

[
  {
    "identifications": {
      "c4cDisplayId": "CRM0815"
    },
    "formattedOrgName": "Pole Guano Inc.",
    "standardIndustrySector": "11",
    "customerClassification": "A",
    "defaultAddress": {
      "country": "AQ",
      "postalCode": "12345",
      "cityName": "Pengu Town"
    },
    "defaultCommunication": {
      "website": "www.pole-guano.aq"
    }
  },
"extensibilityValues": [
      {
        "fieldName": "Ext_Escalation",
        "value": true
      },
      {
        "fieldName": "Ext_EmployeeSize",
        "value": "02"
      },
      {
        "fieldName": "Ext_SecondaryIndustries",
        "value": "17"
      },
      {
        "fieldName": "Ext_SecondaryIndustries",
        "value": "42"
      }
    ]
  }
]

 

Create Contacts and Contact Relations in Accounts

Since the account-based segmentation will return contacts which are related to the segmented accounts, you also need contacts and contact relation to the account. Please check the relevant sections under chapter 'Create Data via API' in my previous post 'Sending Emails on-behalf of Sales Reps - leveraging any CRM System'.

 

Use Account-based Segmentation with Custom Fields

Once you have created custom fields for Corporate Accounts, you can select them in any account-based segment as described in the application help:

If you select the custom field 'Employee Size [Ext]' which has a codelist, then you can select from the previously created options:

Note: Please notice that only those corporate accounts are considered which actually have the specific custom field assigned. For example, if you have an operator like 'does not have any of' (in case of a multi-value field) you will not get results from corporate accounts which do not have the corresponding custom field - although semantically those would fulfill such a condition as well.

 

Conclusion

After reading through this post you should be able to:

  • Create custom fields for the Corporate Account
  • Create or update a Corporate Account including custom fields
  • Using the new custom fields in Account-based Segmentation in Emarsys

entry.title: How to Build and Deploy SAP Fiori List Report Apps on BTP with Build Work Zone
entry.content:
In this blog, I will explain the complete process — from developing an SAP Fiori List Report application leveraging an OData service, to deploying it as an HTML5 app in the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry environment, and finally making it seamlessly accessible through SAP Build Work Zone

Steps to be Followed

  1. Prepare Your OData Service
  •  Develop a CDS View in your backend system or use an existing OData service.
  • To expose a CDS view as OData, add the annotation:
  • @odata.publish: true
  • Save and activate the CDS view.
  • Register the OData service in your SAP system through transaction /n/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE:
    • Click Add Service.
    • Search for your CDS OData service, select it, and assign it to the LOCAL system alias. Activate and test the service in SAP Gateway Client.                                                                    

      2.SAP BTP Destination & Connectivity

  • Configure a destination in SAP BTP Cockpit pointing to your backend system (where OData service is hosted)
  • Subscribe to SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.

      3.Develop Fiori List Report Application in BAS

  • Open SAP Business Application Studio (BAS).
  • Create a new project from template → Select SAP Fiori Generator → Choose List Report Object Page template.
  • Select Data Source → OData Service → Choose the Main Entity with its table type.
  • Add the Deployment Configuration.
  • Select Add Application to Managed Application Router.
  • Add the Semantic Object, Action, and Title → Click Finish.
  • Preview the application.      

                                                                                                                            

        4.Deploy Application to Cloud Foundry

  • Login to the Cloud Foundry environment using the terminal command: cf login
  • Set the target with organization and space: cf target -o <org_name> -s <space_name Example: cf target -o 3144XX6trial -s dev
  • Run build and deployment commands: npm run build & npm run deploy-config
  • Choose the target: Cloud Foundry. Destination Name and Router Module: Add Application to Managed Application Router.
  • The mta.yaml file is created.
  • Build the MTA project.
  • Deploy the MTA archive.
  • The application is successfully deployed to Cloud Foundry.
  • Check under HTML5 Applications and preview your application.                                                                                                                                       
                                                                                  

                                                               

        5.Navigate to SAP Build Work Zone

  1. Navigate to Channel Manager → Refresh the content.
  2. Go to Content Manager / Content Explorer → Add the contents to Business Suite.
  3. In Content Manager, create a Page.
  4. Add Page Title and Description → Save.
  5. Edit the page → Add a Section → Click Add Widget → Save.
  6. Assign the page to the Space.
  7. Navigate to Everyone Role (default role in Business Suite) and assign the specific application.

    Note

    • Go to Business Suite Settings in edit mode.
    • Change the parameters in Display → View Mode → Spaces and Pages – New Experience.
    • Save the changes.
    • Click on Go to Site in Business Suite.                                                                                                                               

                                                                                                                                                                           

Conclusion: With these steps, your SAP Fiori List Report application is now developed, deployed on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, and successfully made accessible via SAP Build Work Zone.

entry.title: Re: Custom Logic App to customize BADI: Philippines VAT S...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I hope the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content.) helps you solve the issue:

To extend the BADI: Philippines VAT Summary List of Importation and include the DATFILEITEMDETAIL_N parameter, you will need to implement custom logic using the Custom Logic app Philippines - Custom Logic for Summary List of Importation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Here are the steps you can follow:

Steps to Extend BADI

  1. Access Custom Logic App: Log in to your SAP S/4HANA Cloud system and navigate to the Custom Logic app.

  2. Create a New Enhancement: Within the app, create a new enhancement implementation for the BADI related to the Philippines VAT Summary List of Importation.

  3. Modify Parameters: In your enhancement implementation, you can define additional parameters such as DATFILEITEMDETAIL_N. You will need to ensure that your logic correctly populates this parameter based on your business requirements.

  4. Test Your Implementation: After implementing the custom logic, test it thoroughly to ensure that the new parameter is correctly included and populated in the BADI.

Additional Considerations

  • Authorization: Ensure that you have the necessary authorizations to access and modify the Custom Logic app.
  • Documentation: Refer to the BADI-specific documentation for detailed guidance on implementing custom logic.

[1] Philippines - Custom Logic for Summary List of Importation

Kind regards,

Henrike

" Account assignment if needed
IF ls_upload-acctasscat IS NOT INITIAL.

ls_praccount-preq_item  = ls_upload-preq_item.
ls_praccount-serial_no  = ls_upload-serial_no.
ls_praccount-asset_no   = lv_asset.          " <-- Use padded value

ls_praccountx-preq_item = ls_upload-preq_item.
IF ls_upload-serial_no IS NOT INITIAL.

ENDIF.
IF ls_upload-sub_number IS NOT INITIAL.

ENDIF.
APPEND ls_praccountx TO lt_praccountx.


    " Call BAPI

*      ls_log-type      = 'S'.

*        ls_log-number    = space.
*        ls_log-message   = ls_return-message.
*        ls_log-type      = ls_return-type.
*        APPEND ls_log TO gt_log.
*      ENDLOOP.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.
ENDFORM.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*

entry.title: Unsupported Features with SAP Datasphere Live Connections in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Cloud folks,

I would like to share some of the information that i searched for..

I faced lot of question after implementing SAC Stories on Live connection and this article helps to them.

when working with an SAC live connection to SAP Datasphere, you experience certain product limitations in SAC

In general, any SAP Datasphere system can be connected to any SAC system via the SAP Datasphere live connection in SAC.
Live connections between SAC and SAP Datasphere can be established across tenants . When using the SAC


– Datasphere live connection, We can build SAC stories or analytical applications that, at the same time, use data from a SAP
Datasphere space, multiple SAP Datasphere spaces, multiple SAP Datasphere spaces in multiple SAP Dataspheres as well as
any additional data sources that you have connected to SAC

When using the SAC – Datasphere live connection, SAC currently has the following product limitations:

Below are the list of  features that are not supported 

Analytics : 
Custom Shapes for Geo Maps are not supported
Version based variance features are not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Version Mapping is not supported for SAP Datasphere data.
Blending is not supported.
Scheduling a Publication is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Linked Dimension is only supported for SAP Datasphere models from the same Space. It is not supported across Spaces.
R-Visualizations are not supported. Note: you can vote for this enhancement request here.
Comment Widgets are not supported
Copy Widgets between stories is not supported
Import Pages from Stories that contain Datasphere models is not supported

JustAsk : 
On-the-fly search with Datasphere models is supported.
Indexing Datasphere models in SAC JustAsk is not supported.
Open in Data Analyzer is not supported
Copy widget to Story is not supported
Stories in Classic Experience
Blending is supported for the following scenarios
SAP Datasphere data with local SAC data
SAP Datasphere data with SAP Datasphere data from the same Datasphere space.
Blending information across Datasphere spaces, or across Datasphere tenants, or blending of Datasphere data with
other Live Connections is not supported.
Using Hyperlinks with the option "Apply selected dimension as filter" enabled across Stories using SAP Datasphere Live
Connections is not supported.
SAP Datasphere Analytic models are not supported

SAP Datasphere Data Types
The following SAP Datasphere Data types are currently not supported in SAP Analytics Cloud:
Bigint
Binary
hana.binary
Large Binary
Large String


Planning
SAC Planning data can now be stored in Datasphere with seamless planning However, planning
still requires the import of data into the SAC model and is not based on the SAP Datasphere live connection 


Smart features
Smart Insights are not supported on SAP Datasphere data. .
Smart Discovery is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Smart Predict is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
SAP Digital Boardroom
Stories built on top of SAP Datasphere live data are not supported in SAP Digital Boardroom.

Regards,

Kartheek Kota

Reference:

https://me.sap.com/notes/2832606

entry.title: Re: SD2 not getting created for RE2 with multiple line it...
entry.content:
You’ve described an Advanced Returns (RE2 → SD2) scenario and I could see from your post, the failure only occurs when multiple line items with batch management are present. This is because, the follow‑up activity logic for SD2 expects a 1:1 mapping between the returned item and the replacement item. When you have multiple items and batch management active, the system tries to carry batch data into the SD2 creation. If it cannot uniquely determine the batch assignment per item, the follow‑on creation fails with the generic “Message not found (in main memory)” error. This is a known limitation/bug in some S/4HANA releases: the follow‑on process doesn’t handle multiple batch‑managed items gracefully.

The workarounds are

  • Create SD2 manually with reference to RE2 (VA01 → Create with Reference). This works even when automatic creation fails.
  • Split the RE2 into single‑line returns orders when batch management is required.

entry.title: Budget Availability Control
entry.content:
Good afternoon, I have configured the budget availability control profile for cost centers in SAP 4/HANA PUBLIC CLOUD. I have created a profile where I added the general ledger hierarchy that I had previously created with a group of accounts that I want to affect the budget, and then I added the tolerance limits.

While testing, I wanted to see how a different account would affect the previously created group but with the same cost center, and I noticed that it consumes the budget.

So far, so good. Having done this, I wanted to see the tolerance limit, so I ran another test with an account loaded in the group and took it to the budgeted limit, and I saw that the limit does not cover it; it only covers it when the amount posted to the other account that does not belong to the group is increased.

Here is a brief example I have made up: Account group (601, 602, 603), budget of €3,000. I post €200 to account (620) and to the same cost center as the group. In the "
Commitments by Cost Center" application, you can visually see the consumption of the remaining €2,800 of the budget. But if I post €2801 to account (601), the limit would not mark 100%, it only does so if I mark €3001. I suppose this is because the system understands that the limit is only reached with accounts that are in the same group.

- Could someone give me more detailed information?
- Why does it appear in the application if it does not belong to the account group and is taking away from my budget?
- And why do I have to count the consumption of the other account that does not belong to the group in order to reach the tolerance limit?

I would appreciate it if someone could help me.

Best regards and thanks in advance.

entry.title: Hello Python: My First Script in SAP BAS Connecting to HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Credit: @Vitaliy-R Your startup blogs kindled my interest to explore working with Python in SAP ecosystem. Python in BAS and Jupyter in BAS 

When I first started exploring SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), I was curious about how Python could fit into the SAP landscape. I’ve mostly associated BAS with HANA artefacts(SQLScript, hdbcalculationview, hdbreptask etc.) and CAP artefacts, so writing a Python script inside BAS felt like venturing into new territory. My goal was simple: write a basic script and connect it to SAP HANA Cloud. What I discovered along the way is that Python not only works smoothly in BAS but also makes it easy to interact with HANA Cloud, opening up opportunities for data exploration, automation, and integration in a way that feels both modern and approachable.

Before jumping into the Python script, I had to get my environment ready in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS). Here’s what I set up:

A BAS dev space with a full-stack cloud application space since it supports multiple runtimes, including Python. I had a space with HANA Native Application type. Since the Python tools extension is not added by default, I edited the space to select the Python tools in the additional extension options. 

HANA Dev Space Python extension

 Note: For initial steps to check the Python version, Jupyter notebook and set ups refer to the blogs listed at the start. 

Use Case: I attempted to achieve the following: 

  • Establish a connection to HANA Cloud
  • Execute an SQL query on a table/view 
  • Display the results

In the BAS, I created a project from Template: SAP HANA Database Project

 

Next step: Create a notebook file. 

My guide to connect to HANA Cloud: Connect to HANA Cloud 

When I first tried importing hdbcli into my Jupyter Notebook within BAS, I ran into the same ModuleNotFoundError. Even though I had already installed hdbcli In the terminal, the notebook kernel wasn’t recognizing it. On some search and prompting with GPT( 😁), I understood that it's a common issue because Jupyter can run in a different Python environment than the terminal. The fix was simple: I ran

import sys
!{sys.executable} -m pip install hdbcli

directly in a notebook cell. This ensures that the HANA client is installed in the same environment as the notebook kernel. After this step, I could successfully import dbapi and connect to HANA Cloud without any errors. It was a small but important lesson about Python environments in BAS, especially when using Jupyter.

With the hdbcli package installed and working in my Jupyter Notebook, I was ready to write my first Python script to connect to SAP HANA Cloud.

In the next cell, I imported hdbcli in this notebook. 

import hdbcli
print(hdbcli.__file__)

 

 The next step was to gain access to the dbapi interface, which allows you to establish connections, execute SQL queries, and fetch results from your HANA Cloud instance. This simple import is the gateway to working with HANA directly from Python.

from hdbcli import dbapi

The next step is to establish a connection to your HANA Cloud instance. This requires specifying the host, port, username, and password.

 After connecting, you can create a cursor object to execute SQL statements. An SQL statement, preferably a Select Query to test the retrieval of data from HANA Cloud. In my case, I used a Select with count on the number of records in a view. Once the variables were ready, execute the connection cursor object.

Note: in the SQL variable, use single quotes and a semicolon at the end of the query. (beginner tip 🙂 )

Now is the time to test the data retrieval from the script and compare it with the Database Explorer.

Drum roll....🥁

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Hurray 🎉

Completing my first Python script in SAP Business Application Studio and connecting it to HANA Cloud was an exciting milestone. From the initial curiosity to the small hurdles like installing hdbcli in the notebook and finally seeing my script return results, every step felt like a mini victory.

That simple output from HANA Cloud made all the effort worthwhile and gave me a real sense of accomplishment.

This experience has sparked my curiosity to explore more complex queries, data analysis, and automation using Python in SAP.

I hope my journey inspires others to take that first step and discover how fun and powerful working with Python and HANA Cloud can be.

Chao.

entry.title: New course: Creating Promotions and Coupons in SAP Commerce Cloud
entry.content:
I'm Charis from SAP CX Product Learning team and I am happy to share some exciting news for SAP Commerce Cloud business users and consultants! A brand-new course has arrived on learning.sap.com:

Creating Promotions and Coupons in SAP Commerce Cloud 

Who actually needs this course?

This course primarily aims to teach Business Users how to set up and execute marketing activities using promotions and coupons in SAP Commerce Cloud. It is a beginner course, targeting students with very little prior SAP Commerce Cloud experience. As this is an entry-level course, it may also be suitable for consultants, developers, or administrators who need to learn the fundamentals of SAP Commerce Cloud functionality surrounding promotions and coupons. The duration of the course will be approximately 3 hours.  

Learning Objectives

At the end of this course, students will be able to create promotions and coupons in SAP Commerce Cloud, activate them, and show the execution on the storefront. They will understand how standard features of SAP Commerce Cloud can be utilized to create promotions and coupons to fit different scenarios, depending on their needs.

The course consists of 3 units:

  • Mastering Promotions in SAP Commerce Cloud: Participants will be able to create out-of-the-box promotions using standard conditions and actions, effectively apply priority and rule groups, and set up and execute promotions in SAP Commerce Cloud.
  • Boosting Promotions with Coupons in SAP Commerce Cloud: This unit teaches how to configure and manage various coupon types within SAP Commerce Cloud, building on previous knowledge of how to effectively use promotion rules in SAP Commerce Cloud.  
  • Executing Promotions in Special Scenarios: This unit explores planning and customizing how promotions appear to customers, using potential promotions to proactively engage shoppers, and leveraging customer coupons to boost support and satisfaction.

The course contains very informative content provided in text, diagrams, videos. At the end of each unit, you will be called to answer on quiz questions which will test your understanding on the topic.

The course is available for everyone and it's free! Complete this course and earn a verifiable SAP Authorized Badge on your learning profile!

entry.title: Re: How to create 2 input control filters dependent on ea...
entry.content:
@Neha311 

What is the larger goal of doing this setup? If it is to allow data input on valid combinations of profit center and project code, Better approach would be to use Validation rules based on attributes. 

If you want to use data based derivation by populating 0's which you need to be very careful then your DA should be based on IF condition check for group

IF[d/PROFITCENTERTEST].[p/GROUP]=[d/PROJECTCODETEST].[p/GROUP] THEN

DATA()=1*0

ENDIF

Make sure you are scoping every other dimensions of the model in MEMBERSET else you will get a data explosion.

Once fact data is set to 0 at valid combination you can set the input controls to cascading to get the desired behavior.

 

Another option is to use scripting to set the dependent input control which is project code in this case.

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: Create Outbound delivery in WM without stock (Public...
entry.content:
Hello @castin 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, it is not possible to merge multiple existing outbound deliveries into one. The ECC feature such as VGM1 is not accessible in the Public Cloud.

What you should do:

When creating a delivery, you can choose to either use 'Create Outbound Deliveries from Sales Orders' or schedule delivery creation in batches. If several sales orders share the same criteria, such as shipping point, customer, and delivery date, the system will merge them into a single delivery.

At the transportation and shipping stage, utilise Advanced Shipping and Receiving ASR or TM integration to consolidate multiple deliveries into a single freight unit or load for execution, while maintaining separate delivery documents.

If more stock arrives later, the system will generate a new delivery each time; it does not merge or update the original.

Merging outbound deliveries after they are created is not supported in Public Cloud EWM. If this is essential, you should submit a request through the SAP Customer Influence programme.

SAP Learning-Processing Outbound Deliveries

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: bapi_pr_create return error
entry.content:
Why you get the “enter asset no.” error in BAPI_PR_CREATE is because, the BAPI is validating the account assignment for category A (asset). Even if you see the asset value during debugging, the BAPI will still error if any of the mandatory account-assignment fields or formats are missing or inconsistent for the posting context (company code, distribution line).

For Account Assignment category A, you should provide the following:

  • Asset main number (ANLN1): 12 characters, left‑padded with zeros.
  • Asset subnumber (ANLN2): 4 characters, left‑padded with zeros.
  • Serial no. (distribution line): Typically “01” for a single account line.
  • Distribution basis: Either set
    • PRACCOUNT-QUANTITY equal to the item quantity, or
    • PRACCOUNT-DISTR_PERC = 100.
  • Item’s account assignment category: PRITEM-ACCTASSCAT = ‘A’ and PRITEMX-ACCTASSCAT = ‘X’.
  • Date formats: All DATS fields must be internal format yyyymmdd (your Excel dd.mm.yyyy must be converted).
  • Company code consistency: The asset must exist in the company code derived from the plant on the PR item; otherwise the asset is “not found,” and the BAPI prompts for asset number.
  •

entry.title: Disable the multi line edit in SAP RAP application in Edit Mode
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

Working with S/4 HANA 2023 FPS03 version.

In an SAP RAP-based Fiori Elements LROP application with oData V4 version, there are two Object Pages involved.

List Report - Displays a list of Objects,  First Object Page - Upon selecting an object from the list, this page a table with line items related to child entities, based on the keys from the parent CDS view.

In the table toolbar on the First Object Page, there will be a Create button (enabled via an association with Create from Parent in the Behavior Definition). Clicking this button navigates to the Second Object Page for creation or update of the line items.

When users click Edit on the First Object Page, all the line items in the table become editable via multi-line edit. However, the requirement is to disable this multi-line edit functionality in the table on the First Object Page. Instead, users should:

Use the Create button to navigate to the Second Object Page to add new line items.

Click on individual rows in the table to navigate to the Second Object Page for updating existing items.

Kindly suggest, how to disable the multi line edit in Edit Mode. Any suggestions, really appreciate it.

Regards,
Venkatesh K

Hint: ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA #Core Data Services (CDS)

The TDR helps you to build a replica of your entire production system in a test tenant.

George

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud V2 Q3 2025 Release Highlights
entry.content:
What is new in SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud version 2?  

Explore a selection of our new features in this blog post and join our webcasts for live demos and comprehensive insights into SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP Service Cloud V2 updates. 

Register for our Q3 2025 customer webcasts  

October 14 webcast 
SAP Service Cloud Version 2, Utilities and SAP Enterprise Service Management: Q3/2025 Release Overview 

October 16 webcast 
SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, Sales and Foundation topics: Q3/2025 Release Overview 

Join us at SAP Connect
Please also join us at the upcoming Customer Experience Connect where we showcase how the latest AI-infused SAP CX solutions optimize operations, generate action-ready insights, and deliver delightful experiences at every step of the customer journey. 
Learn more about the SAP CX portfolio here.

What is new in SAP Sales Cloud V2 

SAP Sales Cloud development continues to focus on enhancing key features and workspaces, embedded AI and generative AI, and improving lead-to-cash process automation. We have incorporated several new features designed to reduce manual tasks that traditionally arise between SFA and ERP processes. Our pace of innovation continues to accelerate, but customer feedback remains a critical aspect of our development. Here are a few of our release improvements that stem from customer requests and feedback.  

UI extensibility and mashup permissions  
Customer engagement can be nuanced and may require greater flexibility to meet ideal customer use cases. To support this, administrators now have greater flexibility configuring workspaces and using mashups to provide access for microphone, notifications, and clipboard. This allows for more seamless engagement and supports situations where use of voice commands or notification loop up is helpful, in addition to improving read/write from and to the system’s clipboard. 

Generative AI Contact and Individual Customer Duplicate Checks 
Maintaining clean and accurate sales data and records are critical for effective sales organizations but duplicate and redundant data remains a plague. Existing SAP Sales Cloud data quality tools do a great job cleansing and harmonizing data, but in situations where there are not exact matches or several spellings some users reported missed matches. The new generative AI duplicate check option throws a larger data analysis net and provides users with actionable results paired with AI driven confidence scores. This allows users to take appropriate action or drill down, ensuring that they can make informed decisions faster.  

Restriction rules for email templates 
Generative email creation linked with templates and user driven email templates can dramatically increase email outreach and response times, but for organizations with several organizational units and geographic locations the number of available options can become confusing for the end user. Now administrators can maintain restriction rules for templates, ensuring users only have access to the right subset of templates. This allows administrators the ability to refine by organizational unit and user role, helping end users quickly choose the right template for their customer engagement needs.  

 Field Query Configuration Improvements and UI Enhancement 

To improve usability and administrator experience, we have added a new tab for configuring field query attributes. Within ‘Extensibility Administration’, users can now sort, filter, and search for relevant attributes. The workspace provides a detailed breakdown and a ‘Show Limits’ toggle. We plan to continue to enhance both extensibility and the ease of use for extensibility administration.  

What is new in SAP Service Cloud  

In SAP Service Cloud, we have incorporated several new features designed to reduce manual workloads, expedite issue resolution, and enhance the overall agent experience. In our upcoming webcast, we will showcase these innovations, along with a range of other advanced capabilities, illustrating how they can streamline operations and elevate customer service.  

Improve case categorization with Business Information Extraction in Cases

 In the previous webcast we introduced Business Information Extraction, an AI feature that enables you to automatically extract key information like product names and serial IDs from customer emails. Now we have expanded the use of Business Information Extraction to Cases and you can use the extracted data to automatically categorize cases for faster and more efficient handling 

Business Information Extraction in Cases 
 

Gain improved insights with enhanced interaction and resolution summaries (machine learning)   
There are new machine learning scenarios designed to enhance interaction and resolution summaries. Sentiment Trends and Sentiment Graph add insights to the interaction summary, allowing service agents to better understand the tone of the customer interactions. You can also add internal and external case notes which are used the AI-generated resolution summary to create a more detailed overview. 

Expedite issue to resolution with the direct integration with SAP Field Service Management  
The new direct integration with SAP Field Service Management simplifies the end-to-end service delivery from the very first customer contact all the way to onsite repair. With a smooth integration between contact center and field service you can shorten resolution time and fix the issue on the first visit.   
 

Utilities customer service: gain improved insights with external alerts and quick view for meters 
For utilities contact centers, we have added new features that bring important insights for customer service agents: 

  • External Alerts: You can now add external alerts to the premise and contract views. These alerts are created in SAP S/4HANA. 
  • Quick View for Meters: In the services or premise tab, you can quickly view all the details of a meter, including the device's location and device location notes. 

Create outbound letters quickly with the OpenText Document Presentment Service integration 
The integration enables agents to quickly create outbound letters using automatically prepopulated fields and brand-aligned templates. This feature allows for the swift creation of professional PDFs, which can be sent as email attachments to customers.


 

Creating outbound letters 

 

More information

For more details on the above release features, check out the following resources: 

  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 What’s New 
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 What’s New 
  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 Release Navigator single access point to release content 
  • SAP Service Cloud V2 Release Navigator 

 

Please share your feedback in a comment and follow our SAP Sales and Service Cloud topic page to connect with the community!

entry.title: Re: Monitoring of expiration date for S-users in SAP ME p...
entry.content:
Hi Pavel,

As described by 2928052 - S-user ID Lifetime information - SAP for Me, administrators are notified on the 1st of each month about all S-user IDs set to expire within the next 90 days. This notification is provided by default. 

Currently, there is no functionality to create a monitoring group for users where a designated email group for carrier administrators would receive expiration notifications a specific number.
However, if this feature would be beneficial for your organization, you can submit an enhancement request through the Feedback channel, as outlined in KBA 3156721 - How to give feedback or share ideas and requirements - SAP for Me .The feedback will be sent to the product team, who will review the customer feedback/requirements on a regular basis.

In the meantime, administrators do have the ability to mass extend the expiration dates for a group of S-user IDs. 

For further guidance on this process, please refer to the following Knowledge Base Articles:
2931034 - How to mass extend the Expiration Date for a group of S-user IDs - SAP for Me
2930885 - How administrators manage the Expiration Date for other S-user IDs - SAP for Me

If you have any additional questions or need further clarification, please feel free to let me know. I am happy to assist! 

Have a nice day!

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: enter a material for item 000010 message no. v1351
entry.content:
The error “Enter a material for item 000010 (Message no. V1351)” typically appears when the system is not able to determine the correct item category or schedule line category for the sales document line item.

Since you have already checked VOV4, VOV5, and the Item Category Group (NORM in MM), here are a few additional points to verify in your O2C setup:

  1. Material Master Data

    • Ensure the material is created in the relevant sales area (Sales Org, Distribution Channel, Division).

    • Check that the material has a valid Sales View, Basic Data, and is not flagged for deletion.

  2. Sales Document Type and Item Category Assignment

    • In VOV4, confirm the correct assignment between Sales Doc Type, Item Category Group (NORM), Usage, and higher-level Item Category.

    • Make sure there is no conflicting or missing entry that prevents item category determination.

  3. Schedule Line Category Determination (VOV5)

    • Verify that the schedule line category is properly maintained for the combination of Item Category + MRP Type.

    • If missing, the system might throw the error when trying to create the item.

  4. Configuration Dependencies

    • Check if the material requires additional settings like availability check, pricing procedure determination, or plant assignment.

    • Make sure the plant is extended in the material master and properly maintained in the sales document line item.

  5. Testing with Another Material

    • Try creating the same sales order with another standard material (same item category group NORM). If it works, the issue may be specific to the problematic material master.

If after these checks the error still persists, please share a screenshot of:

  • The sales order line item overview,

  • Your VOV4 and VOV5 configuration entries for the relevant combination,

  • And the material master sales views.

That will help narrow down whether the issue lies in master data or configuration.
